page.title: 02the Fleetwood Landmark
page.content: This strange structure was erected in 1740 by the Lancaster Commissioners to guide ships to Lancaster Port and Glasson Dock. It was a large wooden pyramid sited in a field on Rossall Grange Farm close to the sea, a mile from Rossall Hall. One of these land- marks was washed away by the strong and stormy weather off Rossall Point. The landmark was called 'The Rossall Landmark'. The Reverend St Vincent Beechey, with a maths teacher from Rossall School witnessed 'the beacon' topple over into the sea. When the lighthouses took over and the Beacon was disused,it became a popular place for young people. The last landmark 60 ft bit the sand in 1924, when a local merchant bought it for firewood. Sunk without trace and still sinking the huge iron cage awaits discovery. All that remains is a circle of stumps.
